headline: Homemade Dog Treats (Peanut Butter and Pumpkin)
description: These crunchy pumpkin dog treats made with peanut butter and whole wheat flour are an easy, tasty, homemade treat that your dog (and your friend's dogs!) will love.

video.description: Treat your furry friends with the flavors of peanut butter and pumpkin!
video.name: Peanut Butter and Pumpkin Dog Treats

name: Homemade Dog Treats (Peanut Butter and Pumpkin)
recipeIngredient: 1 teaspoon water, or more if necessary

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
Combine flour, eggs, pumpkin, peanut butter, salt, and cinnamon in a bowl; stir with a spatula until combined.

Transfer mixture to a work surface and work it with your hands until mixture starts to come together. Add 1 teaspoon water at a time (only if needed) to help make the dough workable, but don't add too much as it should be dry and stiff.
Roll the dough to a thickness of 1/2 inch.
Cut into 1/2-inch pieces and transfer to a baking sheet.
Bake in the preheated oven until dog treats are golden brown and crunchy, about 40 minutes. Let cool before serving to your dog.

review.reviewBody: A friend of of ours made these for our dog. He LOVED them and we love that they're healthy! Will be making these often for him.

My dog adores these! Thank you so much!! I don't understand leaving a 1 star review because you didn't do your part on making sure that your dog doesn't choke on a treat. That 1 star review should be for the owner of the dog, and not the treat recipe.
My basset hound LOVES these treats. Used 4 tablespoons of peanut butter and added 1 cup instant oats, 1/2 cup pumpkin and 2tbsp honey. It's been such a hit, we're gifting it to our neighbors dogs
My dogs love this recipe. No edits needed

My dog loved it. I couldn't find any cinnamon so mine are without it. I made mine using fresh pumpkin puree. I'll definitely be making them again. Since they're human grade I was able to try them and I'm wondering if there's a way to make the pumpkin taste come through more? I added more peanut butter than the recipe called for so maybe that overwhelmed the pumpkin flavour.
It was easy and my puppy loves them. Also, it's nice to know what's in them.
This is the perfect recipe for my french mastiff. He loves them. He loves peanut butter and the pumpkin is good for him. The eggs give him added protein. Thank you for posting the recipe.

Pups loves them! left out cinnamon, increased pumpkin by 2 tbl sp. and used dry pb2 lightly flour board, very sticky dough. I baked long skinny rectangles, like a bread stick, that I can break into small pieces instead of fussy stuff!
My dogs absolutely loved the biscuts made from this recipe. I'm going into the kitchen at this moment to make another batch.
Thanks for the recipe! My dogs love it. It's basic and easy to change. I've even made this recipe for bazaars and Christmas presents. Very popular!
Our puppy loves these!
Baked these for a dog's birthday party! Very easy and quick to make. Thanks for the great recipe :)

I have a small senior dog that has stopped eating his vegetables. Only eating meat he was not getting enough fibre. I made a 1/2 batch of these biscults and he just loves them. Instead of canned pumpkin I used fresh which I cooked in a litte water with a beef cube added, then mashed. I also added about a teaspoon some liver treat "powder" (liver treats I blitz in a blender).

If the FDA allows unhealthy ingredients in our food, I can only imagine what is allowed in pet food. Many labels will say, Made in the USA with imported ingredients. This is why I no longer feed my dog store bought dog treats or food. I have made many batches of these treats and she absolutely loves them. For me, I like to make them crunchy so they can help keep her teeth clean while she's gobbling down her treats. And, I never have to feel guilty for giving her highly processed snacks because these are super healthy. I highly recommend this recipe.
Very easy, inexpensive and my boys love them!

For ease, I roll out the dough on parchment paper and then cut it in one inch squares with a pizza roller. Put the parchment on a cookie sheet and bake. I reduce the bake time so they aren't super crunchy. Baxter doesn't seem to care that they are not shaped like bones :) They freeze well also so you can make a ton to last months.

I used this recipe after having bought a certain brand of bones that had chickpea flour, pumpkin, peanut butter, etc. So I used chickpea flour instead of whole wheat. I also used 1 C pumpkin per other reviews. I added a full tsp of cinnamon. I didn't have to add the water, but I had to add more chickpea flour while rolling out the dough. During the process, the dough really smelled like chickpea flour to an overpowering extent, but after baking, the "bones" smelled amazing - like pumpkin muffins (almost). From the extra pumpkin, it was easier to cut the dough into strips instead of using a cookie cutter. My Chihuahua loves them! :) I gave four stars, because I really don't think whole wheat is any better for dogs than it is for people, and had to use twice the pumpkin as the recipe stated, but it's a good start.
Added 1 ripe banana and 1 cup of sugar free applesauce. 45 minutes to crunchy perfection. Its the only treat I give my St. Bernard.

My Boston Terriers have sensitive stomachs and they usually have issues when trying something new. These sat really well with them. I’ve been giving them these for 3 days now. I only cooked them for 15 minutes, so they are just a perfect hardness. Our Great Pyrenees is usually picky and she loves them too. Thank you for the recipe! Now I want to make homemade dog kibble too. 🙂
These turned out awesome! My Boston x Pug (Bug) loved them. Great recipe, thanks!
Added bacon bits to it and my dog loves them,happy,happy,dog
I made it exactly as written, working and patting the dough by hand. I used a small gingerbread man cookie cutter and the people enjoyed that. The dogs LOVED them!

Made this recipe for three beagles. Substituted whole wheat flour with oat flour that I made. next time I make these I will decrease the cook time from 40 minutes to 35 minutes and increase the amount of peanut butter I put in for more flavor. All in all it’s an easy recipe and all the beagles love them.
Very easy recipe. I used the 1 C pumpkin suggested by many reviewers. I mixed these in the stand mixer with a dough hook. The dough came together beautifully, and my dogs love them.
Made these for the holidays for the new K9 at HPD. He loved them !! I used a gingerbread man cookie cutter
My almost 2 year old black lab/ German shepherd pups love these!
this recipe was so amazing. wish everyone luck who haven't made it yet. perfect for all dogs. even toughs on diets.
I this great I’ve made it like 6 times But I’ll use applesauce added & substitute out pumpkin for sweet potato! My Doxie loves them!!!
Easy to make and my guy loves them. Didn't change a thing. I cut them with a small champagne flute glass. Perfect!
My dogs couldn’t get enough of your Peanut butter pumpkin dog treats, I didn’t make bone shape dog treats I just made them round and I double the ingredients once again love them thank you!!!
My pups love them and so easy to make!

I ground up 2/3 cups of quaker oats and added it into the mixture, the dough was perfect. I didn't measure the PB just put a couple blobs in there. I took the fat end of a frosting tip and made smaller ones for food toppers. My Pyr loves them.
I have a furbaby that has a sensitive stomach and problems with diarrhea. She not only loves these treats she hasn’t had any issues with her stomach. These are the only treads I give her now!

I've been using this recipe for since Katy was eight weeks old. She's Four and a half years old today. I make extra for the her little neighborhood friends. They gobble them right up. I would be very careful with storing. In the refrigerator they will grow mold. I store a lot in the freezer and take a few out at a time. Great recipe.
Added some blueberries.. dogs loved it!

I make these cookies for my Murphy about once a month and he loves them... I have modified the recipe a bit... I use 3 cups of flour, 3 eggs, and an entire small can of pumpkin... Yesterday, I used crunchy peanut butter... Sometimes I grate some carrots into the dough... I use my kitchen shears to cut the cookie dough rather than a knife, I find that to be easier...

My two mini schnauzers loved these! Made them for my younger one's first birthday and they were a big hit. I did put the dough into a silicone pawprint-shaped mold in which they were baked and they looked adorable.
My lab and his friends loved them. Made them into 1/2 inch squares and added finely chopped bacon to the dough (omitted the salt).
Easy to make and my pup Finley loves them. I would like to know how long they last and how to store? Any help would be appreciated. Ty

My brother's dog loves these. Theyre fast and easy to make. I do make some changes. I bake them about 10-15min longer (they dont burn), if I bake them as directed they mold fairly quickly. Even when in air tight containers or vacuum sealed. I also poke holes in the center with toothpicks or a fork, because they puff up quite a lot.
Loved it ! Its my go to recipe now. Dogs love them
Easy to make! My dog loved them!
Otis loves these. I roll out on parchment paper on the cookie sheet. Save’s time and cleanup. Cut with pizza cutter.

My puppy loves this treat. It was so easy to make and I really enjoyed the diversion knowing that I was using my time for making a good treat for my pet. Especially nice because it doesn't cost much to make and helps me give my puppy healthy treat
Turned out great! I used a mixer first and then switched to mixing with hands.

Very easy recipe to make, I added 1 cup of pumpkin and a tea spoon of chia seeds. The treats turned out delicious (our dog thinks so) and even humans approved of the taste. Rolling the dough out took a while, but the result was worth it.
I doubled this recipe and my girls were pacing the kitchen waiting for their treats. If they taste as good as they smell I may try one NOT!
good for the whole family

This recipe is absolutely AMAZING!! I made them for my family’s Golden Retriever, Bumi, and he LOVES them! The may be one of his favorite foods :) The recipe is very simple and fun to make, and so delicious! (For the dog, at least.) If you’re thinking about making this I highly recommend it ^^ Thank you for such a great recipe!! :) :)

I've made these about 5 times so far. I always add a little more pumpkin and peanut butter but otherwise follow the recipe. Then after kneading and rolling out the dough, I cut the dough into thin strips, place the strips on a baking sheet covered with parchment paper, and place them in the oven. Then after they're baked and cooled, I break or cut the strips into small pieces to use for dog treats or training treats and place them in the refrigerator (they can get moldy if kept out more than a few days). I see no need to bake them as dog bone shapes. My 55 lb. English Shepherd absolutely loves these small treats.
Second time making this recipe! The dogs loooove it :) i used the remaining pieces and turned them into pretzels
Comes together in minutes and my pup absolutely loves them.
Doggie and nephew approved! Very simple to make.
My doggies LOVE these biscuits!! I cut them into smaller pieces because if I don't, my little meathead will run outside to bury it for later!! Great bedtime snack!
Dog loved them. Soft in center chewy crisp on outside

I found & made these dog biscuits for our pup & a few puppy friends. But these cookies do not keep stored in a sealed jar in the cupboard. They go Moldy with in 2 days. So if making these you need to put them in the fridge. I personally will not be making these again.

My dog is super picky and suspicious so I was weary about these but wanted healthier treats vs store bought preservative filled. Although skeptical & slow eating the one I gave him, once he realized I wasn’t sneaking him meds, he loved them. They have disappeared from his bed and are either in his belly or buried. Either way I’m glad.

But the baking time is way off. The 1st sheet were very burned at 30 min. Baking tome says 40 min. I baked 2nd sheet for 23 minutes & they are just right. I did substitute almond flour for whole wheat and the dough was perfect but perhaps that affected the baking time.
Awesome recipe! I made sharks, all three of my dogs love ‘em!

made these today. i have three dogs, one that won't eat anything that isn't meat or adjacent. one that will eat just about everything, and one in the middle. none of them were remotely interested. maybe it's good ingredients for the dog, but my critters couldn't be less interested.

Great recipe. Thank you for sharing. Sarge gives this one 4 paws and a tail! I added a third tbsp of peanut butter because I thought the dough was a little dry but ended up having to add more flour by the time I rolled out the dough. I suspect the dough would have been perfect if I hadn't altered the measurements. We still have a few milk bones in the box but Sarge won't eat them now that he has had these treats. Thanks again
My dogs love these
Added more pumpkin and peanut butter, omitted the salt. My dogs AND cat love these ❤️🧡💛
I just baked this delicious cookies 🦴 for my puppies 🐶 they love it 👅
I made these with organic ingredients and the texture was perfect without changing a thing. I rolled and baked on parchment paper.
Every dog I’ve offered these to has loved them!
Great recipe....my dog loves them and I know I am giving her a healthy treat
my chow hounds love them and they're all natural no preservatives
These treats my dogs die for. There healthy and have lots of nutrition in them. They make amazing day to day treats for your dog/ Dogs!

My pup loooves these! We have switched from store bought to just making this fast and easy recipe once a week or so! ( I have a mastiff so treats go fast…) we make some with crunchy peanut butter and some with creamy.

I used a large can of pure pumpkin, 1 teaspoon cinnamon, 4 eggs, 3 cups WW flour, 1 cup Almond flour, 1/2 cup coconut flour, 1/2 cup Kraft peanut butter. These cookies are my husky dogs favorite treat. I love this recipe. My pets always do tricks for these.
My puppies loved them. I did not add water at all. I added an extra egg to the recipe.
My dogs first received these as party favors from our local noontime dod park gathering and they loved them! Thank you for sharing the recipe, Elon!!

I’ve been making these since my first dog was being treated for cancer. It was about the only thing she’d eat after chemo. Now my boy has cancer and we’re going through the same thing. I sometimes substitute oat flour (use a blender or food processor to make oatmeal into oat flour).
I’ve made this recipe at least twice now.,made some for a friend the last batch ,her dogs loved them.I am making a few tiny ones for the cat this time

PRO TIP: The next time you buy store-bought treats, check for a little anti-moisture packet inside, save it, and pop it into whatever container you're storing these treats in. It will help increase the shelf life and keep moisture from molding any treats. Our dog absolutely LOVED these. I don't have a cute cookie cutter that fits for dog treats so i just used a cleaned out small glass jar (grey poupon anyone?) to cut out circles. Because of the shape, some of them kind of pop up and look like little flying saucers. The dog gets so excited eating these that she'll go in the backyard and roll for a bit after having one. That's the highest compliment she could have given me, as she only rolls when she's really happy. My fiance also says she tends to want to "bite his hand off" when he's giving her one of these treats. She just can't wait to get them in her mouf. They make the house smells surprisingly good when I'm baking them too. It's the cinnamon and peanut butter I think. Anyway, 5/5 stars. Love these, will continue to make them and keep refilling the doggie treat jar with these. They're fantastic.

This receipe is amazing. The dogs are gaga about these cookies. I just have to say “want a cookie” and they run to the jar. I used the whole can of pumpkin and kept adding flour until it was the perfect consistency to roll the dough out. I baked them as recommended but after they cooled off I noticed they were still softish so I put them in the air fryer until they hardened up. Easy peasy.

Made this recipe with a few adjustments. Didn't have whole wheat flour so made a mix of buckwheat, oat and all purpose flour. Used a mix of pureed pumpkin and chickpea. Also replaced one egg with a flaxseed egg replacement (1 Tbsp flaxseed, 3 Tbsp water let sit until it becomes slimy). No fancy cutouts. Rolled out in a cookie sheet and cut up in squares with a pizza cutter. Doggies enjoyed!
Easy and my dog liked them
Need slightly more water for the dough to come together. Otherwise good. Bought the cookie cutters on Amazon. Baked at 350 for 35 minutes. Very crunchy.
I made this recipe twice now and my dogs love them.
Simple to make and our dog loved them!
This is my go-to-recipe for my food and they absolutely LOVE them! No changes needed on this recipe. ♥️♥️♥️♥️♥️
Dogs ate them up!

I make these all the time for our three dogs and neighborhood dogs. I usually double the recipe and add 2 teaspoons extra peanut butter. It is easier to work with the dough and it makes it easier to chew for senior pups.
I made them as printed an my dog LOVES them! I am currently making my third patch as Easter gifts for other dogs! I am going to try more pumpkin and no salt this time!

I did as others suggested and doubled the recipe to use the full can of pumpkin. I froze the remaining dough. I made these for my puppy’s 1st birthday and she loved them! The dough held the shape of the cookie cutters very nicely. I don’t think I baked them long enough, however, because the extras molded within days and I had to toss them out. I will try again at Christmas and bake them a little longer.

Oh goodness! Our lab loved these. Modifications and methods: Used AP flour (didn't have whole wheat). Used my food processor on dough function. Rolled between 2 pieces plastic wrap. Cut out using apple corer that had 8 sections. Removed some after 20 minutes to cut smaller for treat ball, then baked another 10 minutes.

i recommend cutting the cook time in half because they were just way too crunchy and hard for my dog when cooked for 40 min so i did 20 and he loved them when softer anddd I added 1 cup of pumpkin to them instead, added more peanut butter for flavour and I forgot the water so it was sticky whoopsies but i rolled out with flour so it was all good in the end thank you:D
Easy recipe, simple wholesome ingredients. Hard to mix! I rolled out and cut the dough into small gingerbread men and my neighbors dog, (whom I care for part-time), loved them!
Substituted Pumpkin with yam so I can have one..lol. Excellent!!

My mix came out pretty gooey without adding water. I used the other half of my pumpkin can which I think had more like 3/4 left in it than half from my wife’s batch. I just kept adding flour till I got it workable. I also ground up the egg shell and added that to the mix for added nutrients.
My baby Polly loves them. EASY EASY EASY Thank you, Ann
I added carrot and mashed with pumpkin - doggy #1 liked them... yet to trial with doggy #2 and doggy #3 as they don’t live with me :)
I subbed banana for pumpkin. Ginger loved it!

I fur baby absolutely loves these! I keep his in a air tight container and they stayed fresh for days! Just be careful with what peanut butter you use! Make sure the peanut butter doesn’t contain xylitol. Definitely will remake soon
Bella loves these!!
I added 3/4 cup of pumpkin, and it worked well, in that I didn't need to add water at all. The dough rolled out well, and most importantly, the dogs love them!
My dog loves these! They have become a staple in our house.

item.name: Homemade Dog Treats (Peanut Butter and Pumpkin)
